div.sent: We are citizens of Bangladesh.
It is situated in the eastern part of the land called Bangla.
Its earlier name was East Bengal.
The western part of Bangla is called West Bengal.
It is a province of India.
In ancient times there was no land called Bangla.
Each area had a separate name.
They are Banga, Samatat, Gaura, Pundra, Harikel and Kara.
In the fourteenth century this area was named Bangalah, Subsequently its name was Bangla.
In ancient times the social, economic and religious aspects were remarkable.
Now we will come to know about these aspects.
From ancient times numerous villages grew up in Bangal.
The social life of the villages was simple because of its geographical features.
Most of the people were farmers and fishermen.
In every village, there was a village council.
This council consisted of local celebrities.
Through the local council the administration of the village would run.
The maintenance of law and order and justice were the responsibility of the village council.
All the needs of the people were met in the village.
For this reason these villages were called self- sufficient.

In every village people would live in harmony.
Various functions and festivals would take place all the year round.
People would enjoy themselves on the occasions.
From ancient times the soil of Bengal was fertile.
The climate was suitable for agriculture.
The fields were ploughed with ploughs fitted with iron files.
Bulls and buffalos were used for ploughing.
The main crops of Bengal were rice and sugarcane.
Rice and fish were their staple foods.
For this reason rice was grown in plenty.
Plenty of fish was available in rivers and canals.
Sweets were people's favourite.
Molasses and sugar would be made from the juice of sugarcane.
In ancient Bengal oatmeal, pulses and oilcakes were grown.
All kinds of spices would be made.
A variety of fruits used to be grown.
Various cash crops were cultivated.
Of the cash crops, jute and cotton were the main.
Clothes would be woven from the cotton produced in the village.
Silk was also cultivated.
Along with agriculture, various kinds of cottage industries grew up in ancient Bengal.
In these cottage industries, mainly cotton and silk clothes were woven.
Clothes would be made of jute also.
In ancient Bengal trade and commerce were in vogue.
Merchants from abroad used to come here.
Merchants from different parts of India also came to Bengal.
In the beginning, a kind of marble was used in business as money.
Later coins made of brass, silver and gold came into vogue.
From ancient times the people of Bengal were believers in religion.
They would believe that the human soul lives on after death.
They used to observe various rituals to pay respects to the dead.
They worshipped the sun, rivers, trees, forests, hills, etc as gods.
They also worshipped different animals.
They used rice, bananas, banana trees, coconut, perfumes, betel leaves, etc in this worship.
They drew lines, blew conch shells and uttered religious notes through the lips.
Later in ancient Bengal, various religious beliefs developed.
Of them, Vedic religion, Jaina religion, Buddhism, Baishnaba religion are the main.
Besides, it is learnt that in the coastal areas, Islam began to be preached.
After the arrival of the Aryans, Vedic religion was on its way.
In course of time this religion spread far and wide.
The Vedas are the sacred books of this religion.
The Vedic religion is called the original religion or Hinduism.
Like the people of Bengal, the Aryans were the worshippers of Nature.
They used to worship various objects of Nature as gods and goddesses.
Temples were built in various parts of Bengal.
In these temples, images of gods and goddesses would be placed.
Arrangements were made for worship.
Flowers, fruits, various kinds of food were offered in honour of the gods and goddesses.
Jaina religion was preached by Mahabir.
The Jainas believed that in the natural process all activities of the world are conducted.
Unlike the Vedic religion there were no strict rules and regulations in Jainasm.
This religion received special adherence in some people.
The places of worship of the Jainas are called Bihara1 or monastery.
Gautama Buddha is the founder of Buddhism.
The principles of Buddhism are simple and straightforward.
The basic teaching of this religion is: non-violence is the best religion.
To Buddhists, it is a great sin to kill living beings.
In ancient Bengal many among the ordinary people accepted this religion.
Towards the end of the ancient period, the Baishnaba religion made its appearance.
The followers of this religion regarded Krishna as a god and Radha as a goddess.
They arrange joyous festivals in honour of Krishna and Radha.

In various settlements of Ancient Bengal different types of culture developed.
But certain common characteristics are found.

They also used to eat meat, pulses and vegetables.
Their favourite foods included milk and milk foods.
dress In Ancient Bengal the main dress of men was dhuti.
Women wore sari, hair styles and used coloured substances.
They were very fond of gold and silver jewellery.
Sports In ancient Bengal various kinds of games and sports were in vogue.
Men were fond of running, boat race, ha du du, wrestling and stick games.
Women were fond of the games like kari, guti, kanamachi and bagbandhi.
At that time, pasha game was also popular.
Both men and women participated in this game.
Festivals In Ancient Bengal numerous festivals were in vogue.
Nobanna, paushparban, holy, charak, gajon, rathjatra, julanjatra, rashjatra, dolejatra, etc deserve special mention.
Besides, Shasti, Gaehalud, Pankhili, etc. were favourite functions.
On these occasions, songs and dances were arranged.
Musical instruments like the drum, the flute, etc were used.
There have been various songs, nursery rhymes, arts, etc. in Bengal from ancient times.
These are important aspects of folk tradition of Bengal.
There have been innumerable songs in Bengal from ancient times.
These songs are called folk songs.
These are composed orally and passed on from mouth to mouth.
The noteworthy songs of that time include baul, jhanpan, kirtan, pachali, etc.
Nursery Rhymes There were in vogue many nursery rhymes from ancient times.
These rhymes are composed on various aspects of social life.
People used hanging pots made of jute and fans made of palmyra leaves.
Earthen pitchers, pots and pans, flower vases, toys, etc. were in vogue.
People made crockery with silver, brass, copper, etc.
They engraved designs on them.
Besides, they painted pictures on them and drew designs in different places.
These are important aspects of our folk art.
Bangladesh is our dear motherland.
We will learn more about our history and culture.
